His next challenge is to rectify that by playing well and scoring more peaches, like United goal No 250. 
“I just have to keep going,” he said. “Obviously I’ve been a bit in and out of the team this season, so my main priority now is to fight for my place in the starting line-up. 
“I want to win my place back. I’ve been in and out of the team and I need to keep trying to perform and score to stay in the team.” Mourinho has other ideas, though 
Jose Mourinho won’t stand in Wayne Rooney's way if he wants a big-money move to China, writes David Anderson. 
Chinese champions Guangzhou Evergrande and Super League rivals Beijing Guoan are prepared to fork out a staggering £700,000-a-week to lure record-breaking Rooney away from Manchester United this summer. Jose Mourinho won't stand in Wayne Rooney's way if he wants to move to China (Photo: Reuters) 
Mourinho understands the 31-year-old United and England skipper, who scored his record 250th goal for the club in Saturday's draw at Stoke, may be tempted because he is no longer a regular under him and says the decision will be Rooney’s. 
“I don’t know, it’s up to him,” said the Special One. “I don’t like to be critical of players who decide to go to China. It’s their life, it’s their organisation of their life, their organisation of their career. 
“The money is huge. The experience can also be interesting. 
“I know some of my colleagues think they are more important than they are and think they can interfere in the lives of other people, but I’m not that sort of guy." United stars facing pay cut if Champions League qualification fails them 
Manchester United stars will reportedly lose a chunk of their wages if the Red Devils fail to qualify for the Champions League again this season, writes James Whaling. 
Players face losing up to 25 per cent of their pay packet should United miss out on the top four, report The Sun. Zlatan Ibrahimovic and Paul Pogba are facing pay cuts if United fail to qualify for the Champions League (Photo: Getty Images) 
Stars who were at Old Trafford last term lost out on money from this season's wage after a fifth-placed finish under Louis van Gaal. 
And the likes of Zlatan Ibrahimovic and Paul Pogba, who arrived over the summer, will suffer the same fate for another failure in the current campaign. 
Pogba earns £290,000-a-week at United following his world-record £89million switch from Juventus, £70,000 more than Ibrahimovic. 
While the likes of Arsenal and Manchester City add to their players' wages for a top-four finish, United deduct for failure to reach Europe's top table. 
The club have already confirmed that the kit deal with Adidas will be slashed by 30 per cent, around £22.5million, for a second consecutive season out of the Champions League. Read More
